questions.text: Renal calculi associated with Proteus infection: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Triple phosphate

 

Explanation:

 

Triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones, are primarily composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate. These stones form in alkaline urine, typically in the presence of urea-splitting organisms such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Pseudomonas species. These bacteria produce urease, which hydrolyzes urea to ammonia, increasing the pH of the urine and promoting the precipitation of phosphate crystals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uric acid: Uric acid stones are usually associated with acidic urine and conditions like gout or hyperuricemia. They are radiolucent and do not form in the presence of Proteus infections.

 

Option C. Calcium oxalate: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of renal calculi. They form in acidic urine and are not specifically associated with Proteus infections.

 

Option D. Xanthine: Xanthine stones are rare and associated with a deficiency of xanthine oxidase. They are radiolucent and not related to Proteus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple phosphate (struvite) stones are associated with Proteus infections and form in alkaline urine due to the production of ammonia by urea-splitting bacteria.

questions.text: Referred pain from ureteric colic is felt in the groin due to involvement of the following nerve? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. D) Genitofemoral

 

Explanation: 

 

The genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2) is responsible for referred pain from ureteric colic felt in the groin. This nerve arises from the lumbar plexus and divides into genital and femoral branches. The genital branch innervates the cremaster muscle and skin of the scrotum or labia majora, while the femoral branch supplies skin over the femoral triangle. When there is ureteric colic, the pain is referred along this nerve pathway to the groin area. The genitofemoral nerve is involved in the cremaster reflex, where scratching the inner thigh causes testicular elevation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Subcostal - This is a terminal branch of the T12 nerve that supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It doesn't have connections to the ureter that would explain referred pain to the groin.
  • Option B. Iliohypogastric - While this nerve (L1) is situated at the posterior surface of kidney, it primarily supplies the skin of the lower abdomen and hip region. It's not the main pathway for ureteric pain referred to the groin.
  • Option C. Ilioinguinal - This nerve (L1) supplies the inguinal region, upper part of scrotum, and root of penis or mons pubis in females. Though it runs near urological structures, it's not the primary nerve mediating referred ureteric pain to the groin.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2) serves as the primary pathway for referred pain from ureteric colic to the groin due to its anatomical course and innervation of genital structures.

questions.text: While performing triage of children who are victims of a school bus accident, which one will you attend to first? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Airway Obstruction

 

The most appropriate answer is airway obstruction.

 

Maintaining a patent airway is crucial for the survival of any trauma patient, especially children. An airway obstruction can quickly lead to severe respiratory distress and, if left untreated, can result in death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 4 Shock: While shock is a critical condition, attending to airway obstruction takes precedence because it directly impacts oxygenation, which is vital for life. Treating shock without addressing airway obstruction may not be effective.

 

Option C. Flail Chest: Flail chest is a serious chest injury, but it may not be an immediate threat to the airway. It should be assessed and treated promptly but is not the first priority compared to airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Severe head injury: Head injuries are also critical, but immediate attention to airway obstruction is necessary to ensure the child's ability to breathe and maintain oxygenation. Head injuries can be assessed and managed after ensuring a clear airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage decisions are to be made by deciding which injuries constitute the greatest immediate threat to life.

 

In general, airway problems are more rapidly lethal than breathing problems › circulation problems > neurologic injuries.

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak. This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut:  Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D. The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:


The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

questions.text: A 6-day old child presents with bilious vomiting with double bubble sign on X-ray. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duodenal atresia

 

A 6-day-old neonate presenting with bilious vomiting and a "double bubble" sign on X-ray is indicative of duodenal atresia. The "double bubble" sign refers to the presence of two distinct air bubbles on the X-ray: one in the stomach and one in the proximal duodenum, separated by an obstruction, which is characteristic of duodenal atresia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infantile pyloric stenosis: This is incorrect because infantile pyloric stenosis typically presents after four weeks of age, not in a neonate. Additionally, the vomiting in pyloric stenosis is non-bilious, and the X-ray would show a single bubble due to stomach distention.

 

Option C. Jejunal atresia: This is incorrect because jejunal atresia presents with a "triple bubble" sign on X-ray.

 

Option D. Ileal atresia: This is incorrect because ileal atresia usually presents with multiple dilated loops of the intestine on X-ray, not a double bubble sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duodenal atresia is diagnosed in neonates presenting with bilious vomiting and a double bubble sign on X-ray, indicating obstruction between the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

When the surgeon returns the entire hernial sac to the abdominal cavity without reducing its contents, this procedure is known as "reduction en masse" of the hernia.

 

Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a hernial sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Double loop of intestine is within a hernia sac with a tight neck.

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Organs like cecum (right) and sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and are present outside the sac.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia (irreducible).

choices.text: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman came with a history of thyroid swelling. FNAC was done and the report was suggestive of papillary carcinoma thyroid. The nodule was "cold" on scan. Which of the following will not be a treatment option for her? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radioiodine ablation of thyroid

 

Radioiodine ablation is typically used after thyroidectomy to eliminate any remaining thyroid tissue and residual cancer cells. However, it is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of harm to the developing fetus from radiation exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Thyroidectomy: This option involves the complete removal of the thyroid gland and is a standard treatment for papillary thyroid carcinoma. However, the timing of the surgery during pregnancy should be carefully considered in consultation with an experienced healthcare team.

 

Option B. Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph Node Dissection: In cases where there is evidence of lymph node involvement or a high risk of lymph node metastasis, total thyroidectomy with lymph node dissection may be recommended to remove affected lymph nodes in the neck. Again, the timing and extent of surgery should be carefully evaluated during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Right Hemithyroidectomy: Right hemithyroidectomy involves the removal of one lobe (half) of the thyroid gland. This procedure is considered when there is a single, localized thyroid nodule or cancer confined to one side of the thyroid gland. However, for papillary carcinoma thyroid, total thyroidectomy is often preferred to ensure complete removal of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiation exposure to the fetus.

 

Therapeutic uses for Radioactive lodine

 

  1. In primary thyrotoxicosis after the age of 45 years.
  2. In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland will still function adequately after radiotherapy.
  3. In papillary/follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I 131 is given.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chef presented with complaints of leg pain and swelling. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with varicose veins. Further examination revealed the presence of skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C4

 

Explanation of the CEAP Classification:

 

The CEAP classification is a system used to categorize venous disease based on clinical, etiologic, anatomic, and pathophysiologic criteria. Here's a breakdown:

 

  • C: Clinical classification
  • E: Etiologic classification
  • A: Anatomic classification
  • P: Pathophysiologic classification

 

The "C" or clinical classification is divided as follows:

 

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins.
  • C3: Edema.
  • C4: Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into:
    • C4a: Pigmentation or eczema.
    • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
    • C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: Skin changes with healed ulceration.
  • C6: Skin changes with active ulceration.

 

In summary, the patient's symptoms of varicose veins combined with skin changes such as eczema and lipodermatosclerosis correspond to the C4 classification in the CEAP system.

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neck

 

Explanation:

 

The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.

 

Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma

 

The image shown is of Whipple’s procedure, which can be done for distal cholangiocarcinoma.

 

  • Whipple's procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, is a complex surgical procedure that involves removing the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the common bile duct, the gallbladder, and sometimes a portion of the stomach.
  • This procedure is typically performed to treat cancer of the pancreas, duodenum, or the ampulla of Vater

 

Distal cholangiocarcinoma is cancer that occurs in the bile ducts, typically in the lower part of the bile duct near the pancreas. The procedure referred to in the question is often associated with the surgical management of distal cholangiocarcinoma. It involves a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy), which is a complex surgical procedure to remove the affected part of the bile duct, pancreas, and small intestine, and then reconstruct the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advanced gastric carcinoma: The management of advanced gastric carcinoma typically involves various approaches, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Surgical procedures such as gastrectomy or lymphadenectomy may be performed depending on the stage and location of the tumor.

 

Option B. Gallbladder carcinoma: Gallbladder carcinoma may be treated with surgical resection, often involving cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) and potentially more extensive procedures if the cancer has spread. However, the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to gallbladder carcinoma.

 

Option D. Chronic calcific pancreatitis: Chronic calcific pancreatitis may require surgical intervention in certain cases, but the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to this condition. Surgical options for chronic pancreatitis may include drainage procedures or resection of the affected pancreatic tissue.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The procedure mentioned in the question, which is often performed to manage distal cholangiocarcinoma, is a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy).

questions.text: Imaging modality of choice for fistula in Ano is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRI

 

Fistula-in-ano is an abnormal tract that communicates between the inner surface of the anal canal and the outer skin. The main concern with this condition is the recurrence after treatment, making accurate mapping of the fistulous tract essential.

 

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is the gold standard for imaging fistula-in-ano. It provides high-resolution images that can accurately detail the course, depth, and branches of a fistulous tract. MRI can also differentiate between active and inactive tracts, identify secondary extensions, and help in delineating the relationship of the fistula with the sphincter muscles. This makes it invaluable for both diagnosis and preoperative planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PET-CT: PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography) is an imaging modality that is primarily used for detecting and monitoring the progression or regression of cancers.

 

Option C. Sinogram: A sinogram involves injecting contrast into the external opening of a fistula to delineate its course and internal opening on radiographs. While it can provide information about the fistula's course, it may not provide comprehensive information about secondary tracts, the condition of the surrounding tissues, or the relationship with the sphincter muscles.

 

Option D. CT: CT (Computed Tomography) can provide a detailed image of the anatomy and can be used to identify fistula-in-ano. However, it may not be as sensitive or detailed as MRI, especially when it comes to evaluating the small intricacies of the fistula tract or its relationship with the sphincter complex.

 

Fistulae are classified according to Park’s classification.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The imaging modality of choice for evaluating fistula-in-ano is MRI due to its high-resolution imaging capabilities, which provide detailed information about the course, depth, branches of the fistula tract, and its relationship with surrounding structures.

questions.text: How is wound infection severity graded? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southampton grading

 

Southampton wound grading system is a scoring system for the severity of wound infection.

 

  • The Southampton Wound Grading System is a widely recognized method for grading wound infection severity.
  • It categorizes surgical site infections (SSI) into different grades based on clinical signs, such as erythema (redness), purulent discharge, and wound breakdown.
  • The grading system allows healthcare providers to classify SSIs as minor, moderate, or severe based on specific criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASA classification: The ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification system is primarily used to assess a patient's overall health and fitness for surgery.

 

  • It does not directly grade wound infection severity.

 

Option B. SIRS criteria (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome): SIRS criteria are used to identify systemic inflammation and are not specific to grading wound infection severity.

 

  • These criteria include parameters like temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and white blood cell count.

 

Option D. APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II): The APACHE II score is a severity of illness scoring system used to assess critically ill patients in intensive care units.

 

  • It does not directly relate to grading wound infection severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Southampton grading:

 

 

In summary, the Southampton grading system is the appropriate option for grading wound infection severity as it provides a structured approach to categorizing surgical site infections based on clinical criteria. This system helps healthcare providers assess the seriousness of wound infections and make appropriate treatment decisions.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is/are true about Crohn’s disease, in contrast to ulcerative colitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

  • Perianal fistulae: Crohn’s disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses, and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease. This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohn’s disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohn’s disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohn’s disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohn’s disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crohn’s disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C) Insulinoma. These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • It is associated with the overproduction of gastrin, which leads to excessive stomach acid production.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

 

Option D. VIPoma:

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

questions.text: Which appendicular carcinoma is most commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritoneii? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucinous adenocarcinoma 

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a rare condition characterized by the presence of mucinous ascites due to the dissemination of mucus-producing cells within the peritoneal cavity.

 

This is a type of cancer that arises from cells that produce mucus, commonly from the appendix. It is the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei, as these malignant cells can spread throughout the peritoneal cavity and secrete mucin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucinous cystadenoma: This is a benign ovarian tumor that can produce mucus, but it is less commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei compared to its malignant counterparts.

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that can occur in the appendix. While they can spread, they are not typically associated with the production of abundant mucin that characterizes pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: This is a benign tumor that can occur in the ovaries and produce a watery serous fluid, not the mucinous ascites seen in pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mucinous adenocarcinoma, particularly of the appendix, is the most common appendicular carcinoma associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei, characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: The procedure in the image shows methylene blue dye being injected in the peritumoral region. What is this procedure used for? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

 

The utility of injection of methylene blue in the region around the tumor is for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB).

 

  • Methylene blue dye, along with other tracers, is commonly employed in sentinel lymph node biopsy procedures. Sentinel lymph nodes are the first lymph nodes that cancer is likely to spread to from a primary tumor. By injecting the dye around the tumor, these sentinel lymph nodes can be identified and biopsied to determine if cancer has spread to them. This helps in staging and planning further treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLN biopsy rationale:

 

Afferent lymphatics from a primary tumor first drain into the sentinel node, before draining into the other nodes.

 

So, if sentinel lymph node is positive, it is possible that the other axillary nodes are also involved. Hence, axillary dissection would be necessary.

 

If the sentinel node is tumor free, then regional nodal metastasis is unlikely.

 

The nodes can be identified using:

 

  • Fluorescein dye
  • Methylene blue
  • Radioactive sulfur colloid-labeled albumin

 

The recommended site of injection is in the subdermal plexus surrounding the nipple.

 

This is used in patients with clinically node-negative disease.

choices.text: TACE is used for multinodular lesions
Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm
The incidence of HCC is increasing
NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC

questions.text: Identify the false statement out of the following: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

 

Lenvatinib is used to treat advanced stages of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Treatment of lesions less than 3 cm is wide excision or liver transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TACE is used for multinodular lesions: True. TACE (Transarterial chemoembolization) combined with other treatments is used for unresectable multiple nodular and massive HCC, especially when a single nodular diameter is greater than 5 cm (intermediate or advanced HCC).

 

Option C. The incidence of HCC is increasing: True. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide due to the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity.

 

Option D. NASH (Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis) and NAFLD (Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease) are risk factors for HCC: True. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NALD), which progresses to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC.
  • Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.
  • Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs.
  • Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

questions.text: A child is having fecal discharge from the umbilicus. What is the abnormality? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Patent vitello-intestinal duct

 

The patent vitello-intestinal duct, also known as a patent omphalomesenteric duct, is an abnormality where the duct that normally connects the yolk sac to the midgut during fetal development fails to close. This duct connects the ileum to the future umbilicus, and if it remains completely patent, it can lead to fecal discharge from the umbilicus, as seen in this case.

 

The persistence of the entire duct results in a direct communication between the ileum and the umbilicus, which can cause fecal matter to be discharged through the umbilicus. This condition is also referred to as an enterocutaneous fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalo-mesenteric cyst: This condition occurs when only a part of the vitello-intestinal duct remains patent in the middle, leading to a cystic swelling along the tract of the former duct. It does not cause fecal discharge from the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Remnant urachus: The urachus is a remnant of the fetal connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. A patent urachus would result in urine discharge from the umbilicus, not fecal discharge.

 

Option D. Omphalocele:  Presents with abdominal wall defect with herniation of intestines covered by peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecal discharge from the umbilicus in a child is indicative of a patent vitello-intestinal duct, which involves the persistence of the fetal duct connecting the ileum to the umbilicus.

questions.text: A patient was admitted after a road traffic accident and later put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes to verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command – 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously – 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, as given here, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ERCP and Bile duct

 

The abdominal X-ray KUB image shows a stent, specifically a double J (DJ) stent, commonly used in surgeries. The appearance and orientation of the stent are key to identifying its location. In this case, the stent is positioned vertically, which indicates it is in the bile duct. The bile duct runs vertically in the body, and a biliary stent used in procedures like ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) would also be oriented vertically. Conversely, a stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally due to the anatomical layout of the pancreatic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP and Pancreatic duct: A stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally, not vertically, due to the horizontal course of the pancreatic duct. The given image shows a vertically oriented stent, which rules out this option.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic balloon catheter: This type of catheter would have a different appearance and is not typically placed in a vertical orientation like the stent shown in the X-ray.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous catheter: This type of catheter is used for different purposes and would not appear as a vertical stent in the abdominal X-ray. It also wouldn't be located in the bile duct or pancreatic duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vertical orientation of a stent on an abdominal X-ray is indicative of its placement in the bile duct, particularly in procedures involving ERCP.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the urologist with complaints of abdominal pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. Upon examination, the physician noted tenderness in the lower abdomen and a palpable mass in the right flank area. Further evaluation revealed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelviureteric junction obstruction

 

The clinical scenario and the imaging indicate a likely diagnosis of pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction.

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition where there is a blockage at the point where the renal pelvis meets the ureter.
  • This blockage can lead to hydronephrosis, which is the swelling of a kidney due to a buildup of urine.
  • PUJ obstruction can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired. Symptoms can include flank pain, recurrent UTIs, and a palpable mass in severe cases.
  • The findings from imaging studies, showing hydronephrosis (dilated pelvicalyceal system), would support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Putty kidney: A putty kidney refers to a kidney that has been extensively damaged by tuberculosis. The kidney appears pale, and is often shrunk, firm, and non-functional. It would not typically cause a palpable mass and recurrent UTIs in the described manner of the patient in the question.

 

Option C. Staghorn calculus: Staghorn calculi are large kidney stones that occupy a large portion of the renal pelvis and its calyces, often having a shape resembling a stag's horn. They can lead to recurrent UTIs and can sometimes be palpable, especially if the kidney is also enlarged due to obstruction. However, the description in the question and the image seems more indicative of an obstruction at the PUJ rather than a staghorn calculus.

 

Option D. Cystic kidney: A cystic kidney, as the name suggests, is characterized by multiple cysts in the kidney. There are several diseases, like polycystic kidney disease, that can lead to cyst formation in kidneys. These cysts can sometimes cause pain, enlarged kidneys, and in some cases, recurrent UTIs. However, the specific findings from the imaging study mentioned in the question don't necessarily align with a simple cystic kidney diagnosis.

 

Given the findings mentioned in the question, a palpable mass in the right flank area, tenderness in the lower abdomen, and imaging results, Pelviureteric junction obstruction (Option A) is the most consistent and likely diagnosis for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition causing blockage where the renal pelvis meets the ureter, leading to hydronephrosis and symptoms like flank pain and recurrent UTIs.
  • Imaging typically shows a dilated pelvicalyceal system.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient undergoes parotidectomy surgery to remove a tumor. During the postoperative period, the patient complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Great auricular nerve

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (specifically, the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the earlobe and the skin over the parotid gland. Damage to this nerve during parotidectomy surgery can lead to loss of sensation in the earlobe area, which could affect the patient's sensation while shaving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the external ear and the temporal region, which if injured gives rise to gustatory sweating or Frey’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Facial nerve: The facial nerve is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression, not sensation. Damage to the facial nerve during parotidectomy surgery can result in facial weakness or paralysis rather than altered sensation.

 

Option D. Marginal mandibular nerve: The marginal mandibular nerve is a branch of the facial nerve and primarily provides innervation to the lower lip. It is not typically involved in sensation during shaving.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nerves that can be injured in parotidectomy and its significance:

 

A) Auriculotemporal nerve injury – Frey’s syndrome

 

B) Great auricular nerve- loss of sensation in area of shaving

 

C) Facial nerve- facial palsy

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bag & Mask ventilation 

 

  • In a neonate presenting with a scaphoid abdomen, certain respiratory interventions need to be carefully considered due to the high risk of underlying conditions like congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). 

 

This is contraindicated in neonates with a scaphoid abdomen suspected of having CDH. The use of positive pressure from bag and mask ventilation can exacerbate the displacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through the diaphragmatic defect, potentially worsening respiratory distress and leading to further compromise of pulmonary function. This method of ventilation can increase the risk of pneumothorax, gastric distention, and further reduce lung volume, which is already compromised in CDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation): Like intubation, IPPV is used via a mechanical ventilator after intubation and can provide controlled and safe respiratory support. It is also appropriate in these scenarios to ensure that airway pressure is managed carefully to avoid exacerbating the hernia.

 

Option C. Intubation: This is the preferred method for securing the airway in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen when CDH is suspected. Intubation allows for controlled ventilation settings, minimizes gastric distension, and helps manage the baby’s respiratory status more effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The critical point in managing a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen, particularly when a condition like CDH is suspected, involves avoiding exacerbation of the hernia through inappropriate respiratory support techniques. Opting for intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation instead of bag & mask ventilation is crucial to prevent further complications and stabilize the infant's condition. Properly securing the airway and ensuring adequate ventilation without increasing the risk of further pulmonary or gastrointestinal injury is essential in the initial management of these patients.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presented with burns injury. She is covered with burns on her head and neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45%

 

To calculate the percentage of burns, the "Rule of Nines" is commonly used in medicine. According to this rule, each area of the body is assigned a percentage value.

 

For example, the head and neck are typically assigned 9%, each upper limb is assigned 9% (18% total for both), and the front and back of the chest are assigned 18%. When we add these percentages together, we get a total of 45% burns.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 45% according to Wallace's rule of nine.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Burns on the head & neck would account for 9% of burns.
  • Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%
  • Burns on both sides of the chest would account for 18%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 9+18+18 = 45%

 

Wallace's rule of nine:

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from height. The patient reports no pain or injury, but on examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. The patient is hemodynamically stable with no other injuries. The next step in management would be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ascending urethrogram

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests a suspected urethral injury with blood at the urethral meatus, which is commonly caused by external trauma or instrumentation.
  •  To confirm urethral rupture, the next step would be an ascending urethrogram.
  • Ascending urethrogram: Correct. In a patient who is hemodynamically stable and without symptoms of a full bladder, retrograde urethrography will help determine the extent of the injury and decide on the next appropriate steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheterization: In the setting of suspected urethral injury, as evidenced by the presence of blood at the tip of the urethral meatus, inserting a Foley catheter can be harmful. It could potentially exacerbate the injury or convert a partial tear into a complete one. Hence, this is contraindicated without first confirming the integrity of the urethra.

 

Option C. Nephrogram: A nephrogram is an imaging study of the kidneys and their function. While it can give details about the upper urinary tract, it's not typically used for evaluating urethral injuries.

 

Option D. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy, or suprapubic catheter placement, involves inserting a catheter directly into the bladder through the abdominal wall. It's done to divert urine when urethral catheterization is not possible or contraindicated, such as in the setting of a known or suspected urethral injury. This will be attempted after an urethrogram confirms a rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management.
  • Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.

choices.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.
Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

 

Laparoscopic surgeries have become popular as they result in lesser post-operative pain, are cosmetically better, and result in an earlier return to normal physiological function (Options A, B, and C). Patients are discharged from the hospital earlier, with a lower incidence of complications, as compared to open surgeries. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer, as it is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

This statement is incorrect. Laparoscopic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays compared to traditional open surgery. Patients typically spend less time in the hospital and recover faster, which is one of the key advantages of this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain: Smaller incisions and less tissue trauma typically result in less post-operative pain compared to traditional open surgery.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions: This is an advantage of laparoscopic surgery. The smaller incisions are not only cosmetically appealing but also result in reduced scarring and a lower risk of wound infections.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function: Patients often recover more quickly and can resume their normal activities sooner due to the minimally invasive nature of the procedure.

choices.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

 

  • The given CT image shows a cyst in the liver is suggestive of hydatid disease with floating membrane sign.
  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog tapeworm.
  • MC site of hydatid cyst in human: liver (MC) followed by pulmonary hydatids (2nd MC)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgery is mandatory: Surgical treatment of hydatid cyst indicated when PAIR is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic: FNAC is contra-indicated as rupture of cyst may lead to spillage or anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. Angioembolization is the treatment of choice:  Angioembolization has no role in the management of hydatid cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT.
  •  The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible.
  •  FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A chronic smoker starts having pain in the calf on walking a distance of 400 meters. Gradually he starts developing pain on walking a distance of as less as 200 meters only. Currently he even gets pain in his calf while lying down. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rest pain

 

History of a chronic smoker with intermittent claudication followed by continuous calf pain even at rest is indicative of Rest Pain. This is seen in Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Diseases (PAD) like Buerger’s disease or atherosclerosis. Rest pain is typically experienced in the feet or toes and can be so severe that it awakens the patient from sleep. Chronic smoking is a significant risk factor for PAD.

 

The progression of symptoms described – from pain with walking decreasing distances to pain even while at rest – fits the pattern of advancing PAD and critical limb ischemia. This patient's history of chronic smoking further aligns with the likelihood of PAD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous claudication:

 

  • Definition: Pain in the limbs due to venous insufficiency, which is caused by problems with the valves in the veins or venous hypertension.
  • Pain Characteristics: In venous claudication, pain typically gets worse on prolonged standing.
  • Suitability: The patient's pain occurs even at rest and while lying down, which is not characteristic of venous claudication.

 

Option B. Neurological claudication:

 

  • Definition: Pain that results from nerve compression, often due to lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • Pain Characteristics: The pain tends to be aggravated by standing or walking and is relieved by sitting or leaning forward.
  • Suitability: The pain from neurological claudication wouldn't typically manifest when the patient is lying down, as described in the scenario. Further, it begins immediately on walking.

 

Option C. Sciatica:

 

  • Definition: Pain radiating down the leg from the lower back, typically due to a herniated disc pressing on a nerve.
  • Pain Characteristics: The pain is often sharp and can be accompanied by numbness or tingling.
  • Suitability: Sciatica doesn't fit the pattern of pain that worsens with specific walking distances and occurs at rest, as described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rest pain in the context of chronic smoking and intermittent claudication progression indicates Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Disease (PAD).

choices.text: Stricture of the bulb of the urethra

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of delayed urinary tract obstructive symptoms after TURP: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bladder neck stenosis

 

Explanation:

 

Bladder neck stenosis, also known as bladder neck contracture, is the most common cause of delayed urinary tract obstructive symptoms following Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP). This condition occurs due to scarring and narrowing at the bladder neck, which can obstruct the flow of urine. It is a recognized late complication of TURP.

 

Late Complications of TURP

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stricture of the navicular fossa: This is a rare complication and not the most common cause of delayed obstructive symptoms post-TURP.

 

Option B. Stricture of the membranous urethra: While urethral strictures can occur after TURP, they are less common than bladder neck stenosis.

 

Option C. Stricture of the bulb of the urethra: Similar to membranous urethra strictures, these are not as frequent as bladder neck stenosis post-TURP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder neck stenosis is the most common cause of delayed urinary obstructive symptoms after TURP.

questions.text: The Hunterian ligature operation is performed for? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aneurysm

 

Explanation:

 

The Hunterian ligature operation refers to proximal ligation of the feeding artery to treat an aneurysm. This surgical technique was pioneered by John Hunter, who recognized that ligating the artery proximal to the aneurysm could reduce blood flow into the aneurysmal sac, allowing it to thrombose and potentially shrink over time. This approach avoids direct manipulation of the aneurysm sac, which historically was a riskier procedure before modern vascular techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Varicose veins Incorrect. The surgical management for varicose veins includes techniques like Trendelenburg operation (flush ligation of great saphenous vein at saphenofemoral junction), stripping, EVLA (Endovenous Laser Ablation), RFA (Radiofrequency Ablation), foam sclerotherapy, and SEPS (Subfascial Endoscopic Perforator Surgery). Hunterian ligation is not used for varicose veins.

 

Option B: Arteriovenous fistulae Incorrect. Management of arteriovenous fistulae typically involves embolization techniques. Simple ligation of the feeding artery alone is specifically mentioned as being "of no lasting value and is actually detrimental as it may preclude treatment by embolisation."

 

Option D: Acute ischemia Incorrect. Acute limb ischemia requires restoration of blood flow, not interruption of it. Treatment involves emergency embolectomy or thrombectomy (using Fogarty balloon catheter), not arterial ligation which would worsen ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hunterian ligature operation involves proximal ligation of the feeding artery to an aneurysm to reduce flow and promote thrombosis of the aneurysmal sac - representing one of the earliest surgical approaches to aneurysm management before modern vascular reconstruction techniques.

questions.text: Which parameter is best used to monitor the adequacy of and guide fluid resuscitation in a patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Urine Output

 

Urine output is the best measure of organ perfusion and the best monitor for adequacy of fluid resuscitation.

 

Adequate end-organ perfusion is best indicated by urine output of >0.5 to 1 mL/kg/h. However, it does not give minute-to-minute values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CVP (central venous pressure): CVP is a poor reflector of preload. Central venous pressure (CVP) is the mean pressure in the superior vena cava, indicating right ventricular end-diastolic pressure or preload. Normal CVP ranges from 2 to 7 mm Hg (3 to 9 cm H20). A sick or injured patient with a CVP <3 mm Hg is presumed to be volume depleted and maybe given fluids with relative safety. However, CVP is unreliable for assessment of volume status or left ventricular function.

 

Option C. Blood pressure: Blood pressure is an important vital sign, but it alone may not provide a complete picture of a patient's fluid status. Hypotension (low blood pressure) can be a late sign of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and normotension (normal blood pressure) does not guarantee adequate tissue perfusion. The level of consciousness is an important marker for cerebral perfusion.

 

Option D. Oxygen saturation: Oxygen saturation (SpO2) measures the amount of oxygen in the blood, and while it is essential for assessing respiratory status, it is not a direct indicator of fluid balance or adequacy of fluid resuscitation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urine output is a valuable and non-invasive parameter for assessing fluid resuscitation. Adequate urine output indicates that the patient's kidneys are functioning well and that they are likely receiving an appropriate amount of fluids. It is a practical and real-time measure of the patient's response to fluid therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemangioma

 

A hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels.

 

The histopathological features of hemangioma include:

 

  • A well-circumscribed lesion composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels.
  • The endothelial cells lining the vessels are flattened and uniform, with minimal mitotic activity.
  • The vessels are often arranged in lobules, with stromal cells separating the lobules.
  • The stromal cells are composed of fibroblasts, myofibroblasts, and/or pericytes.

 

In cases of cavernous hemangiomas, the vessels are larger and more dilated than those in capillary hemangiomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoma: A lipoma is a benign tumor of adipose (fat) tissue and typically presents as a soft, rubbery lump that can be moved with slight finger pressure. On histopathology, a lipoma will show mature fat cells that are uniform in size. They don't exhibit much cellular variability, and there are no vascular proliferations like those seen in a hemangioma.

 

Option B. Fibroadenoma: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor. It's composed of glandular and fibrous tissue. On physical examination, it often feels like a small, rubbery lump that moves around easily within the breast tissue. Histologically, fibroadenomas show a combination of glandular breast tissue and stromal tissue. They are not typically found on the chest but rather within the breast tissue itself, and their histological appearance would not match the vascular features of a hemangioma.

 

Option C. Nevus: A nevus, commonly referred to as a mole, is a benign skin lesion that contains nevomelanocytes. Nevus cells can be found in the epidermis, dermis, or both. Histologically, it would show nests of melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction, and/or in the dermis, depending on the type of nevus. It wouldn't have the vascular structures seen in a hemangioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels, characterized histologically by well-circumscribed lesions composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels arranged in lobules.

questions.text: Identify the technique shown in the image: (FMGE JULY 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pringle technique

 

The image shows a surgical technique where the hepato-duodenal ligament is clamped. This procedure is known as the Pringle maneuver or Pringle technique. The Pringle maneuver is used to control intraoperative liver bleeding by clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein, thereby reducing blood flow to the liver. This maneuver is commonly used in cases of liver trauma or during liver resections to minimize blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cattel’s technique: This is incorrect because Cattel’s technique is used in IVC injury.

 

Option B. Mattox technique: Mattox technique is done in abnormal aortic injury.

 

Option D. Kocherization: This is incorrect because Kocherization refers to the mobilization of the duodenum to expose structures like the pancreas and is used in procedures such as the Whipple procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pringle maneuver involves clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein to control liver bleeding during surgery, by reducing the inflow of blood to the liver.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-functioning adenoma

 

Most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma is Non-functioning adenoma

 

An adrenal incidentaloma is an unexpected adrenal mass detected on imaging not performed for suspected adrenal disease.

 

Non-functioning adrenal adenomas do not secrete hormones in significant amounts to cause clinical syndromes. They are benign tumors that are often discovered incidentally on imaging studies. Histologically, they are similar to hormone-secreting adenomas, but they do not produce clinical symptoms or biochemical abnormalities. They are the most common type of adrenal incidentaloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical Cushing's syndrome: Subclinical Cushing's syndrome refers to the mild or asymptomatic cortisol excess from an adrenal adenoma. These patients lack the full-blown signs and symptoms of overt Cushing's syndrome but might show subtle manifestations of cortisol excess or have abnormal laboratory findings.

 

Option B. Aldosterone producing adenoma: Aldosterone producing adenomas are a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism. They produce excess aldosterone leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. Patients may have suppressed renin levels in the blood due to feedback inhibition from the elevated aldosterone.

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytomas are tumors of the adrenal medulla that produce excessive amounts of catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine). Symptoms often include paroxysms of hypertension, headache, sweating, and palpitations. While these are serious tumors, they are a less common cause of adrenal incidentalomas.

choices.text: Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was diagnosed with breast cancer of 1.2 X 1 cm with positive axillary nodes and underwent treatment for the same. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. How will you follow up the patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual mammogram

 

The most important aspect of breast cancer follow-up is regular surveillance mammograms. Annual mammograms are recommended to monitor for any signs of disease recurrence or new breast cancers. Mammograms are effective in detecting early breast cancer and remain a crucial part of long-term follow-up care for breast cancer survivors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months: Regular liver function testing (LFT) is not typically indicated for breast cancer follow-up. While liver metastases can occur in breast cancer, LFT monitoring is usually reserved for patients on certain medications or with specific clinical indications.

 

Option C. Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months: While tumor markers like CA 15-3 and CA 27.29 can be useful in some cases for monitoring breast cancer, they are not the primary means of follow-up and are not recommended for routine use as they can have limitations in sensitivity and specificity.

 

Option D. Yearly bone scans: Yearly bone scans are not part of routine breast cancer follow-up unless there is clinical suspicion of bone metastases. Performing bone scans annually would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation and costs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of routine physical examination once in 3 months for a year and annual mammogram.

 

Mammography is the only imaging modality required for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. Tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scan currently have no role in follow-up.

 

Guidelines for follow-up:

 

Physical examination:

 

  • For the first 2 years: once every 3 to 6 months
  • For 3-5 years: once every 6 to 12 months
  • After 5 years: Annually

 

Mammography:

 

  • Initially, 6 months after surgery
  • Thereafter, annually.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liposarcoma

 

Liposarcoma is the most commonly observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space. Liposarcomas are malignant tumors that arise from adipocytes and are most frequently located in the retroperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of muscle origin. While it can occur in various parts of the body, it is more commonly associated with pediatric populations in the neck.

 

Option C. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that tends to arise near large joints but can occur anywhere in the body.

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors. While they can occur in various parts of the body, including the retroperitoneum, they are not the most frequently observed tumor in this location. It's also important to note that when associated with certain genetic conditions like Neurofibromatosis type 1, they can be seen in multiple areas of the body, but they still don't surpass liposarcomas in frequency in the retroperitoneal space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins.
  • Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors.
  • The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors.
  • Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma.
  • Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.text: A first year surgery resident, on rotation at a hospital, is tasked with inserting an intercostal drainage tube in a 65-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who was admitted with a severe exacerbation of their symptoms. The surgery resident has previously performed the procedure under supervision, but this is their first time doing it on their own. Which of the following steps is incorrect? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib

 

Explanation:

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube should be inserted along the upper border of the lower rib, not the lower border of the upper rib. This is to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle, which runs along the lower border of each rib (comprising the intercostal vein, artery, and nerve). Inserting the tube along the lower border of the upper rib increases the risk of injuring these critical structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube: The 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line is a commonly selected site for the insertion of an ICD. This location is within the "triangle of safety," which is bounded by the lateral border of the pectoralis major anteriorly, the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, and the horizontal level of the nipple below. This area minimizes the risk of injuring important structures, including the long thoracic nerve and vessels.

 

Option C. Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury: Directing the tube posteriorly initially helps ensure that it enters the pleural space without injuring the lung. Once inside the pleural cavity, the direction of the tube may be adjusted based on the specific indication for the ICD, such as draining an effusion versus a pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Incised and digitally explored: After making a skin incision, blunt dissection and digital exploration are performed to ensure that there are no obstructions or adhesions and to create a safe pathway for the tube. Digital exploration helps confirm that the tube enters the pleural space properly and safely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting an intercostal drainage tube, it is crucial to place the tube along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid damaging the neurovascular bundle that runs along the lower border of the upper rib.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient underwent hernia surgery and complained of a loss of sensations over the root of his penis during his postoperative recovery. The patient reported no prior history of genital trauma or surgery. Which of the following nerves would you suspect to be the cause of the patient's loss of sensation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilioinguinal nerve

 

The ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely nerve to be implicated in this scenario. It provides sensation to the skin over the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum, and can be injured during inguinal hernia repair surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Iliohypogastric nerve: The Iliohypogastric nerve carries sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve rarely causes sensory disturbances in the right iliac fossa due to the rich nerve supply from other sources. However, severing this nerve above the anterior superior iliac spine can lead to weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. Injury to this nerve can also occur following appendicectomy.

 

Option C. The genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve has a genital branch that provides sensation to the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the genital branch can cause loss of sensation in these areas.

 

The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament, but this is not relevant to the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh: The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh a sensory branch of the femoral nerve that supplies sensation to the anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee. Injury to this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas, but is not related to the patient's loss of sensation in the root of the penis.

choices.text: Injury to base of skull - CSF Otorrhea
Penetrating trauma to eye - Battle sign

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match out of the following: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penetrating trauma to eye - Battle sign

 

  • The Battle sign is indicative of a base of skull fracture and not a result of penetrating trauma to the eye.

 

Battle sign refers to bruising that appears over the mastoid bone (located just behind the ear). It is a classic sign of a base of skull fracture, particularly in the posterior cranial fossa. Penetrating trauma to the eye does not produce a Battle sign. Therefore, this statement is incorrect, making it the right answer to the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDH - ipsilateral pupil dilatation: EDH stands for Extradural Hemorrhage, which occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater and the skull. This can lead to an increase in intracranial pressure, which may compress the third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) on the same side of the injury, leading to ipsilateral (same side) pupil dilation. This statement is correct.

 

Option B. Injury to base of skull - CSF Otorrhea: CSF Otorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ear. This can occur when there's a fracture in the base of the skull, which damages the barrier between the subarachnoid space (where CSF is present) and the inner ear, leading to CSF leakage. This statement is correct.

 

Option D. Midbrain injury – gaze paresis: The midbrain, part of the brainstem, is involved in many functions, including the control of eye movements. Damage or injury to the midbrain can affect the cranial nerves responsible for eye movement, leading to gaze paresis, which is an inability or restriction in moving the eyes in certain directions. This statement is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Battle sign is a classic indicator of a base of skull fracture and not associated with penetrating trauma to the eye.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with chest pain and shortness of breath. Further investigation reveals a mediastinal mass on imaging studies. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation. What is the most common type of tumor found in the anterior mediastinum? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The most common anterior mediastinal tumor is thymoma, while posterior mediastinal tumor is neurogenic tumor.

 

The most common mediastinal tumor in children is neurogenic tumor.

 

  • Thymomas are tumors that originate from the thymus gland located in the mediastinum.
  • They account for a significant portion of mediastinal tumors and are the most common type.
  • Thymomas can vary in terms of malignancy, with some being benign (noncancerous) and others being malignant (cancerous).
  • These tumors can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and other symptoms when they grow and press on nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurogenic: Neurogenic tumors, which originate from nerve tissue, are another type of mediastinal tumor found in posterior mediastinum

 

  • Examples of neurogenic tumors include neuroblastoma and ganglioneuroma.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas can occur in the mediastinum but are less frequent than thymomas.

 

  • Lymphomas originate from lymphatic tissue and can be Hodgkin lymphoma or non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option D. Bronchial cyst: Bronchial cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can develop in the mediastinum but are relatively rare compared to thymomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, thymoma is the most common type of tumor found in the mediastinum, and it originates from the thymus gland. When a patient presents with chest pain and shortness of breath and is found to have a mediastinal mass on imaging studies, thymoma is a likely consideration among other possible mediastinal tumors

choices.text: A, B and D are correct

questions.text:
Which of these is/are included as a part of primary survey in trauma? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Endotracheal intubation
B. Chest X-ray
C. Plain CT
D. ICD insertion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and D are correct

 

The primary survey in trauma is a critical initial assessment conducted to identify and manage life-threatening conditions. It follows the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure). The focus is on stabilizing the patient, and only essential interventions are performed during this phase.

 

Option A. Endotracheal Intubation: This is part of airway management in an unstable trauma patient. If the airway is compromised or there is a risk of airway obstruction, endotracheal (ET) intubation is performed immediately to secure the airway.

 

Option B. Chest X-ray: Although a chest X-ray is considered an adjunct to the primary survey, it is often done bedside in the trauma room as part of the initial assessment of breathing and circulation. It is particularly useful for identifying conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or other thoracic injuries that require immediate attention.

 

Option D. ICD Insertion: Intercostal Drain (ICD) insertion is a bedside procedure that can be part of the primary survey if there is a massive pneumothorax or hemothorax. In cases of tension pneumothorax, an immediate needle decompression is performed, followed by ICD insertion, which is critical for patient survival.

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Plain CT: This is not included in the primary survey. CT scans are generally reserved for stable patients as they require the patient to be transported to the radiology department, which is not feasible or safe in an unstable trauma patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the primary survey of a trauma patient, life-saving interventions like ET intubation, bedside chest X-ray, and ICD insertion are performed to stabilize the patient. A CT scan is not part of this immediate assessment and is reserved for stable patients.

questions.text: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Induration

 

ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration.

 

ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

 

ASEPSIS SCORE

 

 

Criterion Not Included: 

 

Option D. Induration: Induration (hardening of the tissue) is not included in the ASEPSIS wound scoring system. The criteria focus on discharge, erythema, separation of tissues, bacterial isolation, and additional treatments rather than tissue induration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ASEPSIS wound scoring system does not include induration as a criterion. It focuses on factors like purulent and serous discharge, erythema, separation of deep tissue, additional treatments, bacterial isolation, and extended hospital stay to evaluate surgical site infections.

questions.text: In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus 

 

Hollow viscus organs such as the small intestine and colon are more commonly affected in seat belt injuries due to their position and vulnerability to compression forces applied by the seat belt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver and spleen: While the liver and spleen can be injured in seat belt injuries, they are not the most commonly affected organs.

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum, being relatively protected by its retroperitoneal location, is less commonly affected in seat belt injuries compared to other abdominal organs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: The pancreas, located deep in the abdomen, can be injured in seat belt injuries, but it is not as commonly affected as other organs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In seat belt injuries, hollow viscus organs, particularly the small intestine and colon, are most commonly affected due to their susceptibility to compression forces, emphasizing the importance of thorough evaluation for intra-abdominal injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following given cancers rarely metastasize to the liver? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prostate

 

Prostate Cancers rarely metastasize to the liver.

 

Prostate cancer tends to metastasize to bones via periprostatic venous plexus (Bateson) rather than the liver. Bone metastases are a hallmark of advanced prostate cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colon: Colon cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver. The liver is one of the most common sites of metastasis for colon cancer, and it frequently spreads to the liver through the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Breast: Breast cancer can metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases in breast cancer are not uncommon, and the liver is considered a potential site of spread for breast cancer cells.

 

Option D. Melanoma: Melanoma is known for its propensity to metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases are common in advanced melanoma cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common malignant tumors of the liver are metastasis. The liver is a common site of metastases from gastrointestinal tumors because of dissemination via the portal venous system. The most relevant such metastatic tumor of the liver to the surgeon is colorectal cancer because of the well-documented potential for long-term survival after its complete resection.

 

The more frequent primary sites include carcinomas of the colon, pancreas, lung, and breast in adults, and neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, and rhabdomyosarcoma in pediatric patients. Although the origin of the tumor is often known when metastases are biopsied, carcinomas of the pancreas, stomach, and lung are particularly notorious for being occult primary neoplasms.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice has a distended gall bladder and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound. Which of the following will be most useful to localize the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

Given scenario of an elderly male with obstructive jaundice and distended gall bladder, is suggestive of periampullary tumour. The best investigation would be a CECT abdomen (not provided in the option) or MRCP.

 

Correct. MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that visualizes the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It provides detailed images without the need for ionizing radiation or invasive procedures. Given the patient's age and presentation, MRCP is an ideal choice to visualize obstructions or abnormalities in the bile duct system without posing additional risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This is a useful modality for visualizing the biliary tree, pancreas, and surrounding structures. It can be particularly helpful in assessing small lesions or stones that might be missed by other imaging modalities.
