It would be utilised if MRCP/CECT did not yield adequate diagnosis, or for staging of periampullary tumors.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography: This is an invasive procedure where contrast is injected directly into the biliary system through the liver, and then X-rays are taken. It can be diagnostic as well as therapeutic (e.g., for bile duct drainage). However, it's more invasive than MRCP and might not be the first choice for solely diagnostic purposes in a 72-year-old patient.

 

Option D. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It involves inserting an endoscope through the mouth to the duodenum and injecting contrast into the bile and pancreatic ducts. While ERCP can visualize and treat obstructions, it's invasive and carries risks like pancreatitis, especially if used primarily for diagnostic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive jaundice is a condition in which there is a blockage of the flow of bile out of the liver. This results in redirection of excess bile and its by-products into the blood, and bile excretion from the body is incomplete

 

Symptoms of obstructive jaundice include yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes; paler stools and darker urine; and intense itching.

 

The most common cause of obstructive jaundice is the presence of CBD stones (choledocholithiasis). Other causes of obstructive jaundice are tumors, trauma, cysts, and inflammation in the bile ducts.

questions.text: Identify the stage of the pressure sore:  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

A stage 4 pressure sore is characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle. The image shows a deep ulcer with visible bone and extensive tissue damage, which are hallmarks of a stage 4 pressure sore. This stage represents the most severe form of pressure ulcer, with significant risk for infection and complications due to the depth of tissue involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: This stage involves non-blanching erythema of intact skin. It is the earliest stage of pressure ulceration, where the skin appears red and does not turn white when pressed.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Stage 2 pressure sores involve partial-thickness skin loss with exposure of the dermis. They may appear as shallow, open ulcers with a red or pink wound bed, without slough or deeper tissue exposure.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 sores show full-thickness skin loss, where subcutaneous fat may be visible but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed. The ulcer may include undermining and tunneling but does not extend into deeper structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 4 pressure sores are the most advanced, involving full-thickness tissue loss with visible bone, muscle, or tendon. Early identification and treatment of pressure sores can prevent progression to this severe stage.

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after an RTA. He has suffered chest trauma, has respiratory rate of 44/min and BP is 90/40 mm of hg. He is conscious and speaks single words. There is a hyper-resonance on percussion on the involved side of his chest. What will be your immediate next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercoastal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for splenectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy because removing the spleen does not address the underlying cause of bone marrow failure. Splenectomy would not provide any benefit in managing or treating bone marrow failure, as the problem lies within the bone marrow's ability to produce blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iatrogenic splenic rupture: This refers to a rupture of the spleen caused inadvertently by medical intervention. In cases of splenic rupture, splenectomy is often necessary to prevent further complications such as internal bleeding.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Splenectomy can be indicated for thrombocytopenia, particularly if it is caused by conditions like Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP), where the spleen destroys platelets.

 

Option C. Splenic infarct with sepsis: In cases where a splenic infarct leads to sepsis, splenectomy may be necessary to remove the infected spleen and control the spread of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy, as the procedure does not address the underlying pathology of bone marrow production issues.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, it is found that the patient is unable to pass urine and there is visible blood at the meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous urethra

 

  • Given the presentation of the patient - specifically the inability to pass urine, visible blood at the meatus after a motor vehicle accident and the RGU appearance - the membranous urethra is the most likely site of injury.
  • This is because it's closely associated with pelvic fractures, which are common in such accidents.
  • The management includes a retrograde urethrogram to confirm the injury, followed by the insertion of a suprapubic catheter to bypass the injured segment and allow for healing.
  • Membranous urethral rupture is typically associated with pelvic fractures and presents with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination.
  • Bruising may also be visible over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis. Urine extravasates in the perivesical space.
  • The membranous urethra is the shortest and narrowest part of the male urethra and passes through the urogenital diaphragm.
  • This segment is particularly vulnerable in cases of pelvic fractures, often seen in motor vehicle accidents.
  • Clinical features, such as blood at the meatus and urinary retention as seen in the case, often point to an injury in this region.
  • On rectal examination, a high-riding prostate may be palpated, indicating disruption of the urethra below the prostate. This choice aligns with the given scenario and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbar Urethra: It's a common site of injury due to straddle injuries (like falling onto a bicycle crossbar) because of its exposed location. It would typically result in a perineal hematoma.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: This occurs due to a blow to the pelvis; however, no blood is seen at the urethral meatus.

 

Option D. Penile Urethra: This portion is within the shaft of the penis, encased within the corpus spongiosum. Trauma to the penile urethra usually results from direct trauma to the penis, such as in the context of a penile fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membranous urethral injuries are common in pelvic fractures, presenting with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and possibly a high-riding prostate on rectal examination. Retrograde urethrogram is used for confirmation.

questions.text: ABCDE rule is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant melanoma

 

ABCDE rule applies to malignant melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABCDE rule for the clinical evaluation of malignant melanoma:

 

A - Asymmetry: One half of the mole does not match the other half.

 

B - Border irregularity: The edges of the mole are irregular, ragged, or blurred.

 

C - Color variation: The mole has different shades of color, such as black, brown, tan, or red.

 

D - Diameter: The mole is larger than 6 millimeters or has grown in size.

 

E - Evolution: The mole has changed in size, shape, or color, or has started to bleed, itch, or crust over.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

 

Gallbladder polyps are growths that emerge from the lining of the gallbladder. Those that are smaller than 10 mm are generally considered less likely to be cancerous. The risk of cancer increases with the size of the polyp, especially if it is larger than 10 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porcelain gallbladder: This condition is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall. It has been associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This is a chronic biliary disease marked by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. People with primary sclerosing cholangitis have an elevated risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and to a lesser extent, gallbladder cancer, especially if they develop gallbladder polyps.

 

Option D. Gallstone >3 cm: Large gallstones, especially those larger than 3 cm, have been linked with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

choices.text: First assessment with sonography in trauma
Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

questions.text: The acronym FAST refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focused assessment with sonography in trauma

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FAST stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma and is a non-invasive, rapid bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen.
  • It is used to evaluate patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries and can be performed within 2-4 minutes.
  • The subxiphoid transverse view is used to assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries.
  • The longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant is used to assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch.
  • The longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant is used to assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • The transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region are used to assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.
  • eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

After breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended. Radiotherapy has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of local recurrence after BCS for DCIS. In this patient, despite having a 7 mm margin clearance, the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS warrants the use of adjuvant radiotherapy to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is primarily used for invasive breast cancers, especially when there is a high risk of systemic spread. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and hence systemic chemotherapy is not typically indicated.

 

Option C. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up: Regular follow-up is crucial for any patient who has undergone treatment for breast cancer, but it is not the primary management strategy immediately after surgery for high nuclear grade DCIS.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used for HER2-positive invasive breast cancers. DCIS that is HER2-positive does not typically receive trastuzumab therapy, as the benefits of such treatment in non-invasive cancer have not been clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.

 

The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.

 

 

Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone

 

7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

10 to 12: Mastectomy

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a noticeable bulge in his lower abdomen that becomes more pronounced when he's in a standing position. Upon examination, hernia is identified located medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia.
  • Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and are located medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • The appropriate surgical method for the management of a direct hernia is the Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • The Lichtenstein mesh repair is a tension-free technique that uses a synthetic mesh to reinforce the weakened area of the abdominal wall.
  •  It is the preferred method for direct hernias due to its lower recurrence rates and faster recovery times.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct hernia and Bassini repair: While the Bassini repair is a traditional method of hernia repair, it involves suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches or conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament without using a mesh. This technique is mainly used in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis but has a high recurrence rate compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option C. Indirect hernia and Bassini repair: Incorrect. Indirect hernias are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and are managed differently. The Bassini repair, as mentioned, is less commonly used today due to its higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair: Incorrect. While the Lichtenstein mesh repair can also be used for indirect hernias, the scenario describes a direct hernia based on its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia is characterized by its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery, and the Lichtenstein mesh repair is the recommended surgical approach due to its efficacy and lower recurrence rates.

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

 

14 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 14 Fr are commonly used in adult female patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Fr: 6 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 6 Fr are commonly used in pediatric patients or in adults with narrow urethras. They are also used in urodynamic studies to measure bladder pressures.

 

Option C. 16 Fr: 16 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 16 Fr are commonly used in adult male patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Option D. 22 Fr: 22 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 22 Fr are commonly used in patients for suprapubic cystostomy. They are also used in patients who have undergone prostate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FOLEY’S CATHETER

 

The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3rd mm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in OPD with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid tumor

 

  • The given clinical scenario and image points to a diagnosis of parotid tumor.
  • MC benign parotid tumor is Pleomorphic Adenoma.
  • MC site: superficial lobe of parotid

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst: Seen in children at lines of mesodermal fusion like outer canthus of eye.

 

 

Option C. Sebaceous cyst: Will show soft consistency and punctum.

 

 

Option D. Swollen cervical lymph node – will show firm consistency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A parotid tumor, particularly pleomorphic adenoma, is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.
  • It is characterized by slow growth, a variable consistency, and mobility, commonly found in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland.
  • Proper diagnosis involves imaging and FNAC, with treatment typically involving surgical removal while preserving the facial nerve if possible.

questions.text: Long lasting results in CABG are obtained when graft is harvested from which blood vessel? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal mammary artery

 

Natural arterial grafts last longer than venous or synthetic grafts. The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is the most preferred vascular graft for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) due to its superior long-term patency rates. This is because the LIMA has a muscular wall that resists atherosclerosis, making it more durable and less prone to occlusion compared to other grafts.

 

Internal mammary artery:

 

  • Location: Runs along the inside of the chest wall.
  • Benefits: The LIMA is often used in CABG because of its proximity to the heart and its superior long-term patency rates. It has a muscular wall that resists atherosclerosis, ensuring longer-lasting results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long saphenous vein:

 

  • Usage: Commonly used due to its length, making it suitable for multiple grafts.
  • Longevity: Vein grafts tend to have higher rates of occlusion over time compared to arterial grafts. They do not have the same durability as arterial grafts and are more prone to developing atherosclerosis.

 

Option C. Poly tetra fluoroethyl:

 

  • Material: Synthetic graft.
  • Usage: Synthetic grafts are generally not the first choice for CABG due to concerns about patency and the risk of complications compared to natural grafts. They are less favored due to a higher risk of thrombosis and occlusion.

 

Option D. Gastroepiploic artery:

 

  • Usage: Less commonly used than the IMA or saphenous vein.
  • Indication: Typically reserved for situations where other preferred graft sources are not available or viable. Its long-term patency rates are not as favorable as the LIMA.

 

Arterial grafts, like the LIMA, are preferred over venous grafts because they have non-collapsible lumens, reducing the risk of thrombosis and occlusion, and providing better long-term outcomes in CABG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is the preferred graft for CABG due to its superior long-term patency rates and resistance to atherosclerosis.

choices.text: Nil per oral to avoid pancreatic stimulation
Parentral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the nil per oral (NPO) approach

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in management of the given condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administration of 5% dextrose 

 

The patient's presentation is suggestive of acute pancreatitis, characterized by severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. The management of acute pancreatitis involves supportive care, including pain management, fluid resuscitation, and nutritional support. 

 

Administering solutions with high glucose content can increase triglyceride levels and potentially exacerbate pancreatitis, especially in a patient who is not eating. This could lead to hyperglycemia, which is why it should be avoided. The fluids preferred are RL or Normal saline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nil per oral (NPO) to avoid pancreatic stimulation: In acute pancreatitis, resting the pancreas by avoiding oral intake is a possible initial management step to prevent further pancreatic enzyme stimulation and reduce pancreatic workload.

 

Option C. Parenteral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the NPO approach: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is generally reserved for patients who cannot meet their nutritional requirements orally or enterally (via the gastrointestinal tract) after several days. The current trend is towards earlier enteral feeding when possible, rather than starting with parenteral nutrition. However, it is not a contra-indication.

 

Option D. Early initiation of oral feedings: If the patient is stable and pain is controlled, early initiation of oral feeding is recommended. This approach has been associated with a shorter hospital stay and lower complication rates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the administration of high glucose content solutions such as 5% dextrose, as they can exacerbate the condition, and instead focus on pain management, fluid resuscitation, and appropriate nutritional support.

questions.text: Which type of intracranial hemorrhage is most likely depicted in the given image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subdural hematoma 

 

The image provided shows a computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain with a collection of blood within the skull but outside the brain tissue. 

 

This type of hemorrhage occurs beneath the dura mater and above the arachnoid layer. It commonly appears as a crescent-shaped collection that can cross suture lines but is limited by dural attachments such as the falx and tentorium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural hemorrhage (also known as epidural hematoma): Typically biconvex in shape and does not cross suture lines due to the firm attachment of the dura to the skull at the sutures. It is often associated with a skull fracture and middle meningeal artery rupture.

 

Option B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Blood is located under the arachnoid membrane, in the subarachnoid space, where cerebrospinal fluid circulates. On a CT scan, it appears as areas of increased density in the sulci and cisterns, rather than a localized collection.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: This is bleeding directly into the brain tissue and appears as a localized area of increased density within the brain parenchyma itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The crescent-shaped collection of blood on a CT scan that can cross suture lines but is limited by dural reflections is indicative of a subdural hematoma, a type of intracranial hemorrhage that occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid layer.

questions.text: A patient suffering from leprosy develops a dirty wound on his foot. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Debride and dressing

 

The image shows a lower limb ulcer in a patient with a history of leprosy. This type of ulcer is typically neuropathic or trophic due to nerve damage caused by leprosy, leading to decreased sensation and subsequent injury. The first and most crucial step in managing such ulcers is debridement and proper dressing. Debridement removes necrotic tissue, slough, and any other debris, which promotes a clean wound environment conducive to healing. Proper dressing keeps the ulcer protected and aids in healing by maintaining an optimal moisture balance.

 

Subsequent steps after debridement include appropriate foot care, offloading pressure from the affected area, and limb rehabilitation to prevent recurrence. However, the immediate next step is to clean the wound, making debridement and dressing the correct initial intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) is the treatment for leprosy to address the underlying infection but does not directly contribute to the healing of an existing ulcer. While MDT is crucial for treating leprosy, it does not manage the wound directly and should not be the first step in ulcer management.

 

Option C. Foot care, limb rehabilitation: Foot care and rehabilitation are essential components of managing neuropathic ulcers, especially in preventing further injuries and recurrences. However, these measures alone will not heal an existing dirty or necrotic ulcer. The ulcer must be cleaned and dressed first before these steps can be effective.

 

Option D. Deformity correction: This will help in healing of ulcer at a later stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of a neuropathic or trophic ulcer in a leprosy patient, the first step should be debridement and dressing to clean the wound. This is followed by comprehensive foot care and rehabilitation to support healing and prevent recurrence.
